metadata.titleEn: Application of tensor CSAMT with high-power orthogonal signal sources in Jiama porphyry copper deposit in Tibet (2021)
metadata.description: The Jiama porphyry copper deposit in Tibet is one of the proven ultra-large-scale copper deposits in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau at present, with the reserves of geological resources equivalent to nearly 20×106 t. However, it features wavy and steep terrain, leading to extremely difficult field operation and heavy interference. This study attempts to determine the effects of the tensor controlled-source audiomagnetotellurics (CSAMT) with high-power orthogonal signal sources (also referred to as the high-power tensor CSAMT) when it is applied to the deep geophysical exploration in plateaus with complex terrain and mining areas with strong interference. The test results show that the high current provided by the highpower tensor CSAMT not only greatly improved the signal-to-noise ratio but also guaranteed that effective signals were received in the case of a long transmitter-receiver distance. Meanwhile, the tensor data better described the anisotropy of deep geologic bodies. In addition, the tests also show that when the transmitting current reaches 60 A, it is still guaranteed that strong enough signals can be received in the case of the transmitter-receiver distance of about 25 km, sounding curves show no near field effect, and effective exploration depth can reach 3 km. The 2D inversion results are roughly consistent with drilling results, indicating that the high-power tensor CSAMT can be used to achieve nearly actual characteristics of underground electrical structures. Therefore, this method has great potential for application in deep geophysical exploration in plateaus and mining areas with complex terrain and strong interference, respectively. This study not only serves as important guidance on the prospecting in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau but also can be used as positive references for deep mineral exploration in other areas.

Verification.Question: Can the high-power tensor CSAMT technique effectively collect data for deep geophysical exploration in regions with complex terrain and strong interference?

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features and advantages of using high-power tensor CSAMT technology for geophysical surveys in complex terrains and high-interference mining areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: high signal-to-noise ratio, high currents, large transmitter-receiver distances, accurately depicts anisotropy, transmission current 60A, transmitter-receiver distance 25km, effective exploration depths up to 3km, realistic subsurface electrical structure characteristics

Quantification.Question: What is the maximum transmission current used in the data collection method for geophysical exploration in complex terrains?

Definition.Question: What does '大功率正交源张量CSAMT' mean in the context of geophysical exploration in complex terrain conditions?
Definition.Answer: In the context of geophysical exploration in complex terrain conditions, '大功率正交源张量CSAMT' refers to a high-power tensor Controlled Source Audio-frequency Magnetotellurics (CSAMT) technique. This method is used to improve the signal-to-noise ratio and obtain effective signals over large distances, even in areas with significant interference and complex topography. It involves using high electric currents to enhance the detection capabilities for deep geological structures, allowing for the characterization of anisotropic properties of subsurface bodies and achieving an exploration depth of up to 3 kilometers.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of high-power tensor CSAMT technology in rugged plateau conditions compare to other geophysical methods in terms of data collection efficiency and signal quality in mineral exploration?
Comparison.Answer: The high-power tensor CSAMT technology significantly enhances the signal-to-noise ratio by providing a large current, ensuring effective signal collection even at long transmission distances. It successfully captures the anisotropy of deep geological bodies, unlike traditional methods that may struggle in such rugged conditions. The technology also maintains sufficient electric field signal strength at distances of around 25 km and effectively maps underground electrical structures to a depth of 3 km, demonstrating its superior data collection efficiency and signal quality in complex terrain and high interference areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges in topographical and interference conditions have led to the use of high-power tensor CSAMT technology in mineral exploration on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complex and rugged terrain conditions of the Tibetan Plateau, along with significant interference due to ongoing development work in the Jiama porphyry copper mining area, have made field operations extremely difficult. These challenges have led to the adoption of high-power tensor CSAMT technology to explore its feasibility in such environments for deep geophysical surveys.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing high-power tensor CSAMT technology in regions with complex terrain and strong interference on the effectiveness of deep geophysical exploration?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing high-power tensor CSAMT technology in regions with complex terrain and strong interference can significantly improve the signal-to-noise ratio and ensure the acquisition of effective signals even at large transmission-receiving distances. This method allows for a clearer depiction of the anisotropy of deep geological bodies and can achieve an effective exploration depth of up to 3 km without near-field effects. The two-dimensional inversion results align closely with drilling outcomes, suggesting that this technology can effectively characterize the underground electrical structure, making it a viable approach for deep geophysical exploration in challenging environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of employing high-power tensor CSAMT technology in geophysical exploration under complex plateau terrain conditions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The ultimate goal of employing high-power tensor CSAMT technology is to explore its feasibility in geophysical exploration under complex plateau terrain conditions and strong interference areas. This approach aims to verify whether this technology can effectively investigate deep geophysical structures in mineral exploration areas, such as the Jiama porphyry copper deposit region in Tibet. The study seeks to improve signal-to-noise ratio, capture effective signals at large transmitter-receiver distances, and accurately depict the anisotropy of deep geological bodies, ensuring reliable underground electrical structure characterization at significant depths.
